from Mrs. Taliaferro expressing her
deep regret at being unable to take
part in the services and gracefully
transferring “all the credit to the
men.”

“Carry Me Back to Old Virginny”
was played by the band, which had
been grouped about the speakers'
stand.

Dr. J. D. Clements paid a brief but
glowing tribute to the memory of
Dr. Reed, in introducing Dr. Law-
rence T. Royster, of Norfolk, who
spoke on “What Walter Reed Means
to Medical Research.” Dr. Royster
opened his remarks with the state-
ment that “birthplace of an immor-
tal” was being dedicated to future
generations of the world, declaring
that “by common consent the name
of Walter Reed is placed in that
galaxy of brilliant investigators,
which includes Pastuer, Koch, Lister,
Jenner, VonBehring, Morton and
Long; and the brilliance of the gal-
axy is increased by the addition of
his name.”

The speaker went into a detailed
account of the early efforts of the
great physician in his war with the
yellow fever plague, of how he gave
himself as a willing sacrifice to the
cause of mankind, stating that
though he has not to lose his life in
his great fight, he risked it gladly,
time and time again. Dr. Royster
painted in glowing terms the charac-
ter and the devotion of the man.

In concluding, the speaker declar-
ed: Although he had not surrendered
his life in the fight at the moment of
victory, in spirit he had made the
great sacrifice, in the interest of
science and for humanity. Greater
love hath no man than this, that he
lay down his life for his friends.
“The spirit of research.”

As Dr. Royster took his seat amid
the applause, the band struck up the
martial strains of “Dixie,” which
served to increase the clatter of ap-
procation from the crowd.

In introducing Col. J. R. Kean, the
Hon. S. Otis Bland, of this city, took
occasion to say a few words in praise
of the state and the county which
“mothered so illustrious a son.” The
Congressman expressed the hope that
some day a history of Tidewater will
be written by one of “her own sons,”
declaring that when it is completed
it will make “an epic to challenge the
admiration of the world.” The speak-
er declared that this section of the
country has a heritage of which it
may well be proud and that it has
been said of its social life that it is
the most hospitable and enchanting in
America.

In introducing Colonel Kean, Mr.
Bland referred to him as “another
distinguished Virginian, a warm,
personal friend of Dr. Walter Reed.”

The man who served in the army
with Dr. Reed and who was his in-
timate friend opened his remarks
with the statement that “In the lives
of great men two places have in
all ages and among all peoples had
a particular interest and sacred qual-
ity that where they were born and
that where, when life is ended their
remains are laid to rest in the last
sleep.” “It was my sad duty on a
November day in 1902 to select a
spot where Walter Reed was to rest
a beautiful hillside in Virginia, over-
looking the Potomac and the Capitol
in that silent city where the soldier
dead of the Republic sleep in their
thousands of consecrated fields that
once belonged to the great Captain
Robert E. Lee. I feel it, therefore,
a great privilege and honor to be
present also at this spot where Wal-
ter Reed was born.”

The speaker then went into a de-
tailed account of the birth, early
life and education of Dr. Reed, car-
rying his hearers with the famous
physician through his early life as
an army doctor on the far flung
frontiers of the nation when he was
anything but famous, though even
then interested in research and lay-
ing the foundation upon which he
was later to build his life's work,
which now stands as an everlasting
monument to him and to his pro-
fession. He told of the great work
which Dr. Reed and his assistants
did in their investigation of the ty-
phoid epidemic, continuing his theme
until he reached the point where the
man in whose memory he was speak-
ing had taken up the battle against
the dread yellow fever, which was
ravaging the land. Every effort was
made to check the disease all to no
avail until finally after months of
work and dangerous risks, Dr. Reed
came to the conclusion that the
mosquito was the transmitter of the
germ. In one year after this dis-
covery, the disease was wiped out.

The life work of the hero of the
medical profession is summed up in
the epitaph on his tomb, Col. Kean
said, quoting: “He gave to man con-
trol of that dreadful scourge, yellow
fever.” The officer concluded with
the statement. “We are here today
to make for Walter Reed that proud
boast of the Roman poet. ‘Exegi
monumentum aere perennius’.”

Dr. Taliaferro then presented Mrs.
Walter Reed, widow of the man who
had been so finely eulogized by the
speakers. Mrs. Reed rose and bowed
amid a spontaneous burst of ap-
plause. The chairman of the com-
mission then introduced the Rev.
James C. Reed, brother of the phy-
sician, who thanked the Society and
all concerned for what they had
done to restore and perpetuate the
birthplace of his illustrous brother.
Dr. Reed then pronounced the bene-
diction which concluded the program.

Mrs. Reed, her guests and other
special guests of the occasion then
held an informal reception in the
house, with tea being served by the
Gloucester County Woman's club.

In addition to Dr. Reed's widow
and brother, Dr. James C. Reed,
among those present were several
daughters of the Dr. James Reed,
with a number of his wife's family
and members of Dr. Reed's sister's
family.

The Walter Reed Memorial Com-
mission of the Medical Society of
Virginia, for the Encouragement of
Research, which holds title to the
property consists of the following:
Dr. E. C. S. Taliaferro, chairman,
Norfolk; Dr. Clarence Porter Jones,
secretary and treasurer, Newport
News; Dr. Greer Baughman, Rich-
mond; Dr. Halstead S. Hedges,
Charlottesville; Dr. Garnett Nelson,
Richmond.

The Woman's Club of Gloucester
County will have charge of the prop-
erty.

Belroi, the birthplace of Dr. Wal-
ter Reed, which was yesterday dedi-
cated as a national shrine to the
memory of the man who gave his
life to the research which was con-
cluded with the discovery by the
great army physician that yellow
fever was carried by the mosquito,
is now as nearly restored to its orig-
inal state as was possible.

The little one and a half story
frame house has been completely re-
stored, inside and out. The house has
been re-roofed, the two chimneys re-
stored, with the original brick, The
interior has been completely over-
hauled and furnished, under the di-
Gloucester County. Dr. Clarence
Porter Jones, of the commission,
stated that it was the hope of the
society to be able to rebuild the log
kitchen which stood in close proxim-
ity to the house, and to erect a perm-
anent fence about the grounds.
